        I *think* a malicious web developer can circumvent the time check with service worker.<span class="line"><!---->I *think* a malicious web developer can circumvent the time check with service worker.<!----></span><br><br>// In sw<span class="line"><!---->// In sw<!----></span><br>let flag = true;<span class="line"><!---->let flag = true;<!----></span><br>const init = ...;<span class="line"><!---->const init = ...;<!----></span><br>const bodyA = ...;<span class="line"><!---->const bodyA = ...;<!----></span><br>const bodyB = ...;<span class="line"><!---->const bodyB = ...;<!----></span><br>self.addEventListener('fetch', (e) => {<span class="line"><!---->self.addEventListener('fetch', (e) =&gt; {<!----></span><br>  const req = e.req;<span class="line"><!---->  const req = e.req;<!----></span><br>  if (req.url === ...) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (req.url === ...) {<!----></span><br>    e.respondWith(new Response(flag ? bodyA : bodyB, init));<span class="line"><!---->    e.respondWith(new Response(flag ? bodyA : bodyB, init));<!----></span><br>    flag = !flag;<span class="line"><!---->    flag = !flag;<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br><br>My assumptions (possibly wrong) here is, the response time for a response created in a service worker is always 0.<span class="line"><!---->My assumptions (possibly wrong) here is, the response time for a response created in a service worker is always 0.<!----></span><br><br>This service worker serves two responses for the same URL, and the same response time and different bodies.<span class="line"><!---->This service worker serves two responses for the same URL, and the same response time and different bodies.<!----></span><br><br>+flaken@, please correct me if I'm wrong.<span class="line"><!---->+flaken@, please correct me if I'm wrong.<!----></span><br><br>Thanks,<span class="line"><!---->Thanks,<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I don't immediately know, sorry. I believe the response time check that code caching uses was always meant to be a short-term solution: see <span class="line"><!---->I don't immediately know, sorry. I believe the response time check that code caching uses was always meant to be a short-term solution: see <!----></span>issue 1099587<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1099587" title="Use unique identifier rather than timestamps for verifying V8 code cache entries"><!---->issue 1099587<!----></a>. As<span class="line"><!---->Stop storing the ScriptCachedMetadataHandler in RawResource. As<!----></span><br>RawResource has only one client, we can dispatch the given cached<span class="line"><!---->RawResource has only one client, we can dispatch the given cached<!----></span><br>metadata without compromising ownership. Have BodyStreamBuffer store<!----></span><br>the ScriptCachedMetadataHandler so that the WASM implementation can<span class="line"><!---->the ScriptCachedMetadataHandler so that the WASM implementation can<!----></span><br>get the handler easily.<span class="line"><!---->get the handler easily.<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1146673<a class="strike-through" target="_blank"         This bug has been closed for more than 14 weeks. Removing security view restrictions.<span class="line"><!---->This bug has been closed for more than 14 weeks. Removing security view restrictions.<!----></span><br><br>For more details visit <span class="line"><!---->For more details visit <!----></span>https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage"><!---->https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage<!----></a> - Your friendly Sheriffbot<span class="line"><!----> - Your friendly Sheriffbot<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Description #1 by wfh@chromium.org (Nov 6, 2020)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by wfh@chromium.org (Nov 6, 2020)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by wfh@chromium.org (Nov 6, 2020)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by wfh@chromium.org (Nov 6, 2020)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      See parent bug for full exploit. This is for the wasm part.<span class="line"><!---->See parent bug for full exploit. This is for the wasm part.<!----></span><br><br># Renderer Bug<span class="line"><!----># Renderer Bug<!----></span><br><br>## Details<span class="line"><!---->## Details<!----></span><br><br>When compiling large wasm code, chrome would serialize the compiled code as code cache and reuse it if the wasm resource is requested a second time. For now, WebAssembly caching is only implemented for the streaming API calls such as `compileStreaming`.<span class="line"><!---->When compiling large wasm code, chrome would serialize the compiled code as code cache and reuse it if the wasm resource is requested a second time. For now, WebAssembly caching is only implemented for the streaming API calls such as `compileStreaming`.<!----></span><br><br>However, the validation of wasm cache hit is insufficient. If attacker<span class="line"><!---->However, the validation of wasm cache hit is insufficient. If attacker<!----></span><br><br>1. Fetch a wasm resource (called *res_a*) from server without any cache control hint. and then<span class="line"><!---->1. Fetch a wasm resource (called *res_a*) from server without any cache control hint. and then<!----></span><br>2. Fetch a wasm resource with the same origin, but this time, the server will return a different resource file (called *res_b*) and tell chrome to cache it.<span class="line"><!---->2. Fetch a wasm resource with the same origin, but this time, the server will return a different resource file (called *res_b*) and tell chrome to cache it.<!----></span><br>3. Compile *res_a* , and chrome would reuse the code cache generated for *res_b* which results in type confusion.<span class="line"><!---->3. Compile *res_a* , and chrome would reuse the code cache generated for *res_b* which results in type confusion.<!----></span><br><br>## Exploitation<span class="line"><!---->## Exploitation<!----></span><br><br>Untagged WebAssembly global values are stored in a ArrayBuffer. The bounds check of accessing a global value is done in compile phase. As such, we can cause OOB access on partition heap by leveraging the type confusion bug and then achieves RCE.<span class="line"><!---->Untagged WebAssembly global values are stored in a ArrayBuffer. The bounds check of accessing a global value is done in compile phase. As such, we can cause OOB access on partition heap by leveraging the type confusion bug and then achieves RCE.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        We use the resource URL as the key, so I think a robust fix for this would be to generate a checksum on the code in the browser process to prevent the server from switching the contents as above.<span class="line"><!---->We use the resource URL as the key, so I think a robust fix for this would be to generate a checksum on the code in the browser process to prevent the server from switching the contents as above.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1146673#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Sun, Nov 8, 2020, 10:07 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1146673#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Sun, Nov 8, 2020, 10:07 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        I'm not sure how the first "confused" fetch can get the cached module from the second caching fetch. My understanding of ResourceLoader is that the code cache fetch is started at the same time as the resource fetch. Is it possible for the second fetch to generate the code and cache it before the first fetch tries to get it?<span class="line"><!---->I'm not sure how the first "confused" fetch can get the cached module from the second caching fetch. My understanding of ResourceLoader is that the code cache fetch is started at the same time as the resource fetch. Is it possible for the second fetch to generate the code and cache it before the first fetch tries to get it?<!----></span><br><br>To clarify my suggestion in #8, I think the resource checksum must be computed in the renderer, as the browser wouldn't have an easy way to associate the code with the resource. The checksum could be appended to the resource URL used as a key to prevent this confusion.<span class="line"><!---->To clarify my suggestion in #8, I think the resource checksum must be computed in the renderer, as the browser wouldn't have an easy way to associate the code with the resource. The checksum could be appended to the resource URL used as a key to prevent this confusion.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        Perhaps the Blink RawResource corresponding to the Wasm fetch is keyed by URL leading to the code cache fetch being associated with the first Wasm fetch.<span class="line"><!---->Perhaps the Blink RawResource corresponding to the Wasm fetch is keyed by URL leading to the code cache fetch being associated with the first Wasm fetch.<!----></span><br><br>Another thought is that JavaScript may not have the same problem because they are not explicitly fetched like streaming Wasm resources.<span class="line"><!---->Another thought is that JavaScript may not have the same problem because they are not explicitly fetched like streaming Wasm resources.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Nov 9, 2020, 8:14 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        > My understanding of ResourceLoader is that the code cache fetch is started at the same time as the resource fetch. Is it possible for the second fetch to generate the code and cache it before the first fetch tries to get it?<span class="line"><!---->&gt; My understanding of ResourceLoader is that the code cache fetch is started at the same time as the resource fetch. Is it possible for the second fetch to generate the code and cache it before the first fetch tries to get it?<!----></span><br><br>Yes, that's my understanding too. The fetch (both code cache and the resource) is asynchronous. So, I could imagine the case (though unlikely) where the second fetch is serviced before the first one. Though we match response times to ensure that the cached code corresponds to the fetched resource [1]. So I am not sure how how we could use the wrong code.  Is there a case where the response time matches for the first and second requests? I thought if they are different resources I think response_time would be updated too.<span class="line"><!---->Yes, that's my understanding too. The fetch (both code cache and the resource) is asynchronous. So, I could imagine the case (though unlikely) where the second fetch is serviced before the first one. Though we match response times to ensure that the cached code corresponds to the fetched resource [1]. So I am not sure how how we could use the wrong code.  Is there a case where the response time matches for the first and second requests? I thought if they are different resources I think response_time would be updated too.<!----></span><br><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/loader/fetch/resource_loader.cc;l=380;drc=b6ce9909d733600593342da7f9d153d5cd9c532e;bpv=1;bpt=1<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/loader/fetch/resource_loader.cc;l=380;drc=b6ce9909d733600593342da7f9d153d5cd9c532e;bpv=1;bpt=1"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/loader/fetch/resource_loader.cc;l=380;drc=b6ce9909d733600593342da7f9d153d5cd9c532e;bpv=1;bpt=1<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        In the Wasm case, we have to try to retrieve the resource using the URL from the ResourceFetcher.<span class="line"><!---->In the Wasm case, we have to try to retrieve the resource using the URL from the ResourceFetcher.<!----></span><br><br>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/bindings/core/v8/v8_wasm_response_extensions.cc;drc=2ac4fdcdc1247f058a77900dc4af2b597a3a60d1;l=210<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/bindings/core/v8/v8_wasm_response_extensions.cc;drc=2ac4fdcdc1247f058a77900dc4af2b597a3a60d1;l=210"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/bindings/core/v8/v8_wasm_response_extensions.cc;drc=2ac4fdcdc1247f058a77900dc4af2b597a3a60d1;l=210<!----></a><br><br>ResourceFetcher maintains a cache, keyed by URL.         any chance the cache entry for the first fetch is kept open for the duration for the second? If so, they may end up sharing the entry; a solution may be be to Doom the currently open entry for a key on Write (just dooming it by key before create may be enough and I think should perform OK).<span class="line"><!---->any chance the cache entry for the first fetch is kept open for the duration for the second?           <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1146673#c20">Comment 20<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Nov 9, 2020, 11:29 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Hi, hope this helps.<span class="line"><!---->Hi, hope this helps.<!----></span><br><br>1. > any chance the cache entry for the first fetch is kept open for the duration for the second? <span class="line"><!---->1. &gt; any chance the cache entry for the first fetch is kept open for the duration for the second? <!----></span><br><br>The first fetch of .wasm resource did not generate any cache, because the web server didn't set any cache control hint in the response HTTP headers.<span class="line"><!---->The first fetch of .wasm resource did not generate any cache, because the web server didn't set any cache control hint in the response HTTP headers.<!----></span><br><br>2. The second time web server would set 'last-modified' in headers and we compile the .wasm resource using `compileStreaming`. In this case, Chrome would cache both the .wasm resource and the compiled wasm code.<span class="line"><!---->2. The second time web server would set 'last-modified' in headers and we compile the .wasm resource using `compileStreaming`. In this case, Chrome would cache both the .wasm resource and the compiled wasm code.<!----></span><br><br>3. Chrome use the URL as key to search existing resource cache, so when compiling .wasm resource fetched in the first time, Chrome would think that there already exists resource cache and then try to get corresponding code cache.<span class="line"><!---->3. Chrome use the URL as key to search existing resource cache, so when compiling .wasm resource fetched in the first time, Chrome would think that there already exists resource cache and then try to get corresponding code cache.<!----></span><br><br>Although the response_time of two fetches are different, Chrome did not verify it before using the code cache. So I think computing a checksum and verify it later, or just verifying the response_time is good enough to fix this bug.<span class="line"><!---->Although the response_time of two fetches are different, Chrome did not verify it before using the code cache. So I think computing a checksum and verify it later, or just verifying the response_time is good enough to fix this bug.<!----></span><br><br>I've tested the fix in #15, it prevents the type confusion and throws a js exception : "Uncaught (in promise) CompileError: WebAssembly.compileStreaming(): Compiling function #5:"get_2" failed: invalid global index: 2 @+46066".<span class="line"><!---->I've tested the fix in #15, it prevents the type confusion and throws a js exception : "Uncaught (in promise) CompileError: WebAssembly.compileStreaming(): Compiling function #5:"get_2" failed: invalid global index: 2 @+46066".<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        </div>

        I *think* a malicious web developer can circumvent the time check with service worker.<span class="line"><!---->I *think* a malicious web developer can circumvent the time check with service worker.<!----></span><br><br>// In sw<span class="line"><!---->// In sw<!----></span><br>let flag = true;<span class="line"><!---->let flag = true;<!----></span><br>const init = ...;<span class="line"><!---->const init = ...;<!----></span><br>const bodyA = ...;<span class="line"><!---->const bodyA = ...;<!----></span><br>const bodyB = ...;<span class="line"><!---->const bodyB = ...;<!----></span><br>self.addEventListener('fetch', (e) => {<span class="line"><!---->self.addEventListener('fetch', (e) =&gt; {<!----></span><br>  const req = e.req;<span class="line"><!---->  const req = e.req;<!----></span><br>  if (req.url === ...) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (req.url === ...) {<!----></span><br>    e.respondWith(new Response(flag ? bodyA : bodyB, init));<span class="line"><!---->    e.respondWith(new Response(flag ? bodyA : bodyB, init));<!----></span><br>    flag = !flag;<span class="line"><!---->    flag = !flag;<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br><br>My assumptions (possibly wrong) here is, the response time for a response created in a service worker is always 0.<span class="line"><!---->My assumptions (possibly wrong) here is, the response time for a response created in a service worker is always 0.<!----></span><br><br>This service worker serves two responses for the same URL, and the same response time and different bodies.<span class="line"><!---->This service worker serves two responses for the same URL, and the same response time and different bodies.<!----></span><br><br>+flaken@, please correct me if I'm wrong.<span class="line"><!---->+flaken@, please correct me if I'm wrong.<!----></span><br><br>Thanks,<span class="line"><!---->Thanks,<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

I believe the response time check that code caching uses was always meant to be a short-term solution: see <span class="line"><!---->I don't immediately know, sorry. I believe the response time check that code caching uses was always meant to be a short-term solution: see <!----></span>issue 1099587<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1099587" title="Use unique identifier rather than timestamps for verifying V8 code cache entries"><!---->issue 1099587<!----></a>. <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>a8b46244ecaa1647ee2d70304878c0365ee04087<a class="undefined" target="_blank" &lt;<!----></span>bbudge@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/bbudge@chromium.org"><!---->bbudge@chromium.org<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Wed Match response to cached raw resource<!----></span><br><br>- Verifies that the retrieved resource has the same response time, and<span class="line"><!---->- Verifies that the retrieved resource has the same response time, and<!----></span><br>  that the source matches (i.e. both are from service worker, or both<span class="line"><!---->  that the source matches (i.e. both are from service         Information for merge decision:<span class="line"><!---->Information for merge decision:<!----></span><br><br>1. Does your merge fit within the Merge Decision Guidelines?<span class="line"><!---->1. As<span class="line"><!---->Stop storing the ScriptCachedMetadataHandler in RawResource. As<!----></span><br>RawResource has only one client, we can dispatch the given cached<span class="line"><!---->RawResource has only one client, we can dispatch the given cached<!----></span><br>metadata without compromising ownership. Have BodyStreamBuffer store<span class="line"><!---->metadata without compromising ownership. Have BodyStreamBuffer store<!----></span><br>the ScriptCachedMetadataHandler so that the WASM implementation can<span class="line"><!---->the ScriptCachedMetadataHandler so that the WASM implementation can<!----></span><br>get the handler easily.<span class="line"><!---->get the handler easily.<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1146673<a class="strike-through" target="_blank"         This bug has been closed for more than 14 weeks. Removing security view restrictions.<span class="line"><!---->This bug has been closed for more than 14 weeks. Removing security view restrictions.<!----></span><br><br>For more details visit <span class="line"><!---->For more details visit <!----></span>https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage"><!---->https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage<!----></a> - Your friendly Sheriffbot<span class="line"><!----> - Your friendly Sheriffbot<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

    <mr-comment headinglevel="2" commenterismember=""></mr-comment>
    <mr-comment-list headinglevel="2"></mr-comment-list>
      
    <mr-issue-details class="main-item"><!---->

      <style>
        mr-issue-details {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background-color: var(--chops-white);
          padding-bottom: 1em;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;

        Description #1 by wfh@chromium.org (Nov 6, 2020)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by wfh@chromium.org (Nov 6, 2020)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by wfh@chromium.org (Nov 6, 2020)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by wfh@chromium.org (Nov 6, 2020)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      See parent bug for full exploit. This is for the wasm part.<span class="line"><!---->See parent bug for full exploit. This is for the wasm part.<!----></span><br><br># Renderer Bug<span class="line"><!----># Renderer Bug<!----></span><br><br>## Details<span class="line"><!---->## Details<!----></span><br><br>When compiling large wasm code, chrome would serialize the compiled code as code cache and reuse it if the wasm resource is requested a second time. For now, WebAssembly caching is only implemented for the streaming API calls such as `compileStreaming`.<span class="line"><!---->When compiling large wasm code, chrome would serialize the compiled code as code cache and reuse it if the wasm resource is requested a second time. For now, WebAssembly caching is only implemented for the streaming API calls such as `compileStreaming`.<!----></span><br><br>However, the validation of wasm cache hit is insufficient. If attacker<span class="line"><!---->However, the validation of wasm cache hit is insufficient. If attacker<!----></span><br><br>1. Fetch a wasm resource (called *res_a*) from server without any cache control hint. and then<span class="line"><!---->1. Fetch a wasm resource (called *res_a*) from server without any cache control hint. and then<!----></span><br>2. Fetch a wasm resource with the same origin, but this time, the server will return a different resource file (called *res_b*) and tell chrome to cache it.<span class="line"><!---->2. Fetch a wasm resource with the same origin, but this time, the server will return a different resource file (called *res_b*) and tell chrome to cache it.<!----></span><br>3. Compile *res_a* , and chrome would reuse the code cache generated for *res_b* which results in type confusion.<span class="line"><!---->3. Compile *res_a* , and chrome would reuse the code cache generated for *res_b* which results in type confusion.<!----></span><br><br>## Exploitation<span class="line"><!---->## Exploitation<!----></span><br><br>Untagged WebAssembly global values are stored in a ArrayBuffer. The bounds check of accessing a global value is done in compile phase. As such, we can cause OOB access on partition heap by leveraging the type confusion bug and then achieves RCE.<span class="line"><!---->Untagged WebAssembly global values are stored in a ArrayBuffer. The bounds check of accessing a global value is done in compile phase. As such, we can cause OOB access on partition heap by leveraging the type confusion bug and then achieves RCE.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        We use the resource URL as the key, so I think a robust fix for this would be to generate a checksum on the code in the browser process to prevent the server from switching the contents as above.<span class="line"><!---->We use the resource URL as the key, so I think a robust fix for this would be to generate a checksum on the code in the browser process to prevent the server from switching the contents as above.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="Last visit > 30 days ago" hidden="">schedule</i>
      bbudge@chromium.org<a id="user-link" href="/u/1212561004" title="bbudge@chromium.org"><!---->bbudge@chromium.org<!----></a>
      bbudge@chromium.org<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->bbudge@chromium.org<!----></span>
      Last visit > 30 days ago<div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="Last visit > 30 days ago" hidden=""><!---->Last visit &gt; 30 days ago<!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Sun, Nov 8, 2020, 10:07 AM EST
    <chops-timestamp title="Sun, Nov 8, 2020, 10:07 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1146673#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Sun, Nov 8, 2020, 10:07 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1146673#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Sun, Nov 8, 2020, 10:07 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        I'm not sure how the first "confused" fetch can get the cached module from the second caching fetch. My understanding of ResourceLoader is that the code cache fetch is started at the same time as the resource fetch. Is it possible for the second fetch to generate the code and cache it before the first fetch tries to get it?<span class="line"><!---->I'm not sure how the first "confused" fetch can get the cached module from the second caching fetch. My understanding of ResourceLoader is that the code cache fetch is started at the same time as the resource fetch. Is it possible for the second fetch to generate the code and cache it before the first fetch tries to get it?<!----></span><br><br>To clarify my suggestion in #8, I think the resource checksum must be computed in the renderer, as the browser wouldn't have an easy way to associate the code with the resource. The checksum could be appended to the resource URL used as a key to prevent this confusion.<span class="line"><!---->To clarify my suggestion in #8, I think the resource checksum must be computed in the renderer, as the browser wouldn't have an easy way to associate the code with the resource. The checksum could be appended to the resource URL used as a key to prevent this confusion.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2" commenterismember=""></mr-comment>

        Perhaps the Blink RawResource corresponding to the Wasm fetch is keyed by URL leading to the code cache fetch being associated with the first Wasm fetch.<span class="line"><!---->Perhaps the Blink RawResource corresponding to the Wasm fetch is keyed by URL leading to the code cache fetch being associated with the first Wasm fetch.<!----></span><br><br>Another thought is that JavaScript may not have the same problem because they are not explicitly fetched like streaming Wasm resources.<span class="line"><!---->Another thought is that JavaScript may not have the same problem because they are not explicitly fetched like streaming Wasm resources.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        > My understanding of ResourceLoader is that the code cache fetch is started at the same time as the resource fetch. Is it possible for the second fetch to generate the code and cache it before the first fetch tries to get it?<span class="line"><!---->&gt; My understanding of ResourceLoader is that the code cache fetch is started at the same time as the resource fetch. Is it possible for the second fetch to generate the code and cache it before the first fetch tries to get it?<!----></span><br><br>Yes, that's my understanding too. The fetch (both code cache and the resource) is asynchronous. So, I could imagine the case (though unlikely) where the second fetch is serviced before the first one. Though we match response times to ensure that the cached code corresponds to the fetched resource [1]. So I am not sure how how we could use the wrong code.  Is there a case where the response time matches for the first and second requests? I thought if they are different resources I think response_time would be updated too.<span class="line"><!---->Yes, that's my understanding too. The fetch (both code cache and the resource) is asynchronous. So, I could imagine the case (though unlikely) where the second fetch is serviced before the first one. Though we match response times to ensure that the cached code corresponds to the fetched resource [1]. So I am not sure how how we could use the wrong code.  Is there a case where the response time matches for the first and second requests? I thought if they are different resources I think response_time would be updated too.<!----></span><br><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/loader/fetch/resource_loader.cc;l=380;drc=b6ce9909d733600593342da7f9d153d5cd9c532e;bpv=1;bpt=1<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/loader/fetch/resource_loader.cc;l=380;drc=b6ce9909d733600593342da7f9d153d5cd9c532e;bpv=1;bpt=1"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/loader/fetch/resource_loader.cc;l=380;drc=b6ce9909d733600593342da7f9d153d5cd9c532e;bpv=1;bpt=1<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        any chance the cache entry for the first fetch is kept open for the duration for the second? If so, they may end up sharing the entry; a solution may be be to Doom the currently open entry for a key on Write (just dooming it by key before create may be enough and I think should perform OK).<span class="line"><!---->any chance the cache entry for the first fetch is kept open for the duration for the second?         Hi, hope this helps.<span class="line"><!---->Hi, hope this helps.<!----></span><br><br>1. > any chance the cache entry for the first fetch is kept open for the duration for the second? <span class="line"><!---->1. &gt; any chance the cache entry for the first fetch is kept open for the duration for the second? <!----></span><br><br>The first fetch of .wasm resource did not generate any cache, because the web server didn't set any cache control hint in the response HTTP headers.<span class="line"><!---->The first fetch of .wasm resource did not generate any cache, because the web server didn't set any cache control hint in the response HTTP headers.<!----></span><br><br>2. The second time web server would set 'last-modified' in headers and we compile the .wasm resource using `compileStreaming`. In this case, Chrome would cache both the .wasm resource and the compiled wasm code.<span class="line"><!---->2. The second time web server would set 'last-modified' in headers and we compile the .wasm resource using `compileStreaming`. In this case, Chrome would cache both the .wasm resource and the compiled wasm code.<!----></span><br><br>3. Chrome use the URL as key to search existing resource cache, so when compiling .wasm resource fetched in the first time, Chrome would think that there already exists resource cache and then try to get corresponding code cache.<span class="line"><!---->3. Chrome use the URL as key to search existing resource cache, so when compiling .wasm resource fetched in the first time, Chrome would think that there already exists resource cache and then try to get corresponding code cache.<!----></span><br><br>Although the response_time of two fetches are different, Chrome did not verify it before using the code cache. So I think computing a checksum and verify it later, or just verifying the response_time is good enough to fix this bug.<span class="line"><!---->Although the response_time of two fetches are different, Chrome did not verify it before using the code cache. So I think computing a checksum and verify it later, or just verifying the response_time is good enough to fix this bug.<!----></span><br><br>I've tested the fix in #15, it prevents the type confusion and throws a js exception : "Uncaught (in promise) CompileError: WebAssembly.compileStreaming(): Compiling function #5:"get_2" failed: invalid global index: 2 @+46066".<span class="line"><!---->I've tested the fix in #15, it prevents the type confusion and throws a js exception : "Uncaught (in promise) CompileError: WebAssembly.compileStreaming(): Compiling function #5:"get_2" failed: invalid global index: 2 @+46066".<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I *think* a malicious web developer can circumvent the time check with service worker.<span class="line"><!---->I *think* a malicious web developer can circumvent the time check with service worker.<!----></span><br><br>// In sw<span class="line"><!---->// In sw<!----></span><br>let flag = true;<span class="line"><!---->let flag = true;<!----></span><br>const init = ...;<span class="line"><!---->const init = ...;<!----></span><br>const bodyA = ...;<span class="line"><!---->const bodyA = ...;<!----></span><br>const bodyB = ...;<span class="line"><!---->const bodyB = ...;<!----></span><br>self.addEventListener('fetch', (e) => {<span class="line"><!---->self.addEventListener('fetch', (e) =&gt; {<!----></span><br>  const req = e.req;<span class="line"><!---->  const req = e.req;<!----></span><br>  if (req.url === ...) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (req.url === ...) {<!----></span><br>    e.respondWith(new Response(flag ? bodyA : bodyB, init));<span class="line"><!---->    e.respondWith(new Response(flag ? bodyA : bodyB, init));<!----></span><br>    flag = !flag;<span class="line"><!---->    flag = !flag;<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br><br>My assumptions (possibly wrong) here is, the response time for a response created in a service worker is always 0.<span class="line"><!---->My assumptions (possibly wrong) here is, the response time for a response created in a service worker is always 0.<!----></span><br><br>This service worker serves two responses for the same URL, and the same response time and different bodies.<span class="line"><!---->This service worker serves two responses for the same URL, and the same response time and different bodies.<!----></span><br><br>+flaken@, please correct me if I'm wrong.<span class="line"><!---->+flaken@, please correct me if I'm wrong.<!----></span><br><br>Thanks,<span class="line"><!---->Thanks,<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

I believe the response time check that code caching uses was always meant to be a short-term solution: see <span class="line"><!---->I don't immediately know, sorry. I believe the response time check that code caching uses was always meant to be a short-term solution: see <!----></span>issue 1099587<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1099587" title="Use unique identifier rather than timestamps for verifying V8 code cache entries"><!---->issue 1099587<!----></a>. Has the change landed and been verified on ToT?<span class="line"><!---->3. Has the change landed and been verified on ToT?<!----></span><br>4.         The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src.git/+/56eb8f649c94ccbd928299db50fdbd4ab3feb949<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src.git/+/56eb8f649c94ccbd928299db50fdbd4ab3feb949"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src.git/+/56eb8f649c94ccbd928299db50fdbd4ab3feb949<!----></a><br><br>commit <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>56eb8f649c94ccbd928299db50fdbd4ab3feb949<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/56eb8f649c94ccbd928299db50fdbd4ab3feb949"><!---->56eb8f649c94ccbd928299db50fdbd4ab3feb949<!----></a><br>Author: Yutaka Hirano <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Yutaka Hirano &lt;<!----></span>yhirano@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/yhirano@chromium.org"><!---->yhirano@chromium.org<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Mon Nov 16 16:36:41 2020<span class="line"><!---->Date: Mon Nov 16 16:36:41 2020<!----></span><br><br>Stop storing CachedMetadataHandler in RawResource<span class="line"><!---->Stop storing CachedMetadataHandler in RawResource<!----></span><br><br>We tried to match a blink::Response with the corresponding<span class="line"><!---->We tried to match a blink::Response with the corresponding<!----></span><br>blink::RawResource to get the ScriptCachedMetadataHandler stored in the<span class="line"><!---->blink::RawResource to get the ScriptCachedMetadataHandler stored in the<!----></span><br>RawResource, but we failed to do that, and the failure led to a security<span class="line"><!---->RawResource, but we failed to do that, and the failure led to a security<!----></span><br>issue.<span class="line"><!---->issue.<!----></span><br><br>Stop storing the ScriptCachedMetadataHandler in RawResource. As<span class="line"><!---->Stop storing the ScriptCachedMetadataHandler in RawResource. As<!----></span><br>RawResource has only one client, we can dispatch the given cached<span class="line"><!---->RawResource has only one client, we can dispatch the given cached<!----></span><br>metadata without compromising ownership. Have BodyStreamBuffer store<span class="line"><!---->metadata without compromising ownership. Have BodyStreamBuffer store<!----></span><br>the ScriptCachedMetadataHandler so that the WASM implementation can<span class="line"><!---->the ScriptCachedMetadataHandler so that the WASM implementation can<!----></span><br>get the handler easily.<span class="line"><!---->get the handler easily.<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1146673<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1146673" title="Security: type confusion in wasm cache"><!---->Bug: 1146673<!----></a><br>Change-Id: I7001d64d24e3085dceb8e165a80fa4043418263b<span class="line"><!---->Change-Id: I7001d64d24e3085dceb8e165a80fa4043418263b<!----></span><br>Reviewed-on: <span class="line"><!---->Reviewed-on: <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2534570<a class="undefined" target="_blank"            issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>

          Blocked on issues<span>Blocked on issues</span>
          
            close<i class="material-icons">close</i>
          <button aria-label="close">
            <i class="material-icons">close</i>
          </button>
        <h3 class="medium-heading">
          <span>Blocked on issues</span>
          <button aria-label="close">
            <i class="material-icons">close</i>
          </button>
        </h3>
        
        
          
            
            
              Issue<th><!---->Issue<!----></th>
            
              Summary<th><!---->Summary<!----></th>
            
          <tr>
            
            <!---->
              <th><!---->Issue<!----></th>
            <!---->
              <th><!---->Summary<!----></th>
            <!---->
          </tr>

          
        <tbody>
          <tr>
            
            <!---->
              <th><!---->Issue<!----></th>
            <!---->
              <th><!---->Summary<!----></th>
            <!---->
          </tr>

          
        </tbody><table><tbody>
          <tr>
            
            <!---->
              <th><!---->Issue<!----></th>
            <!---->
              <th><!---->Summary<!----></th>
            <!---->
          </tr>

          
        </tbody></table>
      <chops-dialog closeonoutsideclick="">

          <button aria-label="close">
            <i class="material-icons">close</i>
          </button>
        </h3>

      </chops-dialog>

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
<script type="text/javascript" nonce="">
 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
</script>
